title: CSS Padding
subject: CSS
theory:
The CSS `padding` properties are used to generate space around an element's content, **inside** of any defined borders.

Like margins, you can target individual sides: `padding-top`, `padding-right`, `padding-bottom`, `padding-left`.

examples.output: The text inside the div is pushed 50px away from the border on all sides.
examples.explanation: Padding increases the effective size of the element unless box-sizing is used.

common_mistakes.mistake: Forgetting padding adds to total width
common_mistakes.correction: A 300px width div + 20px padding = 340px total width (default behavior).
common_mistakes.example: Use box-sizing: border-box to fix this.

interview_questions.question: Does padding accept negative values?
interview_questions.answer: No, unlike margins, padding cannot be negative.

practice_problems.problem: Set top padding to 10px and all other sides to 0px using shorthand.

real_world_use_cases.description: Buttons need padding to look clickable and contain their text comfortably.

exam_notes: Padding background color is governed by the element's background property.
Padding is part of the 'Clickable' area of an element.
summary: Padding cushions your content. It is essential for readability and aesthetic component design.
